description.value: Head bead.    Head bead of usual Semitic type in opaque dark-grey-green glass. Eyes formed of globes of translucent light blue-green glass. Opaque yellow threads run from the nose to the ears. Suspension loop of the body glass to which is attached a metal, apparently iron, loop. The bead served as the pendant of an earring. Probably this was a principal function of these beads.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Head bead.    Of cylindrical form representing a black African in opaque black glass in the body of which are scattered red threads. The curly hair is represented by small glass discs. The heavy lips are in yellow glass. The large eyes are opaque white with the pupils of black glass in high relief. The suspension loop is lost. Brown core.

description.value: One ear-ring, one spacer-bead, three beads in different shapes and materials. A: One penannular ear-ring made of a glazed composition, now yellow and green in colour with a whitish corrosion layer. One finished end preserved, the rest broken off, semi-circular in section.  B: One spacer-bead, two and a half segments preserved, made of light turquoise faience.   C: One short cylindrical bead made of turquoise faience. D: Half a spherical glass bead, with white glass filaments as inlays running around the body. Perlescent corrosion layer apart from the white filament. E: One disc-shaped bead made of ostrich eggshell.

description.value: Fragments of an ear-ring and 11 beads in different shapes and materials. A: Three joining fragments of a penannular ear-ring, made of light turquoise glass, no finished end preserved. Roughly rounded in section. With inner groove similar to shell ear-rings. B: Six segmented cylindrical beads, three larger than the others with up to 10 segments preserved. All made of turquoise faience. C: One ring shaped bead, perforation off centre, made of turquoise faience. D: Two flattened spherical beads, one made of light green glass, the other of vivid turquoise faience. E: One disc-shaped bead made of turquoise faience. F: Fragment of a green to turquoise glass bead, possibly inlays of other material or other coloured glass, now lost.

description.value: Three ear-rings, four beads made in different shapes and materials. A: Two fragments of penannular ear-rings, one made of jasper, the other of carnelian. Both are triangular in section, have notches at the outer edge and a circumferential incised line running parallel to the edge. Each has one original end preserved, the other broken off. The outer surface is well smoothed, the inner shows traces from the drill. The carnelian one is slightly smaller. B: One fragment of a penannular ear-ring made of jasper. Rounded triangular in section, the outer surface is well smoothed, both ends broken off. The inner surface shows traces from the drill. C: One cylindrical shaped bead with a facetted surface made of what looks like a blue stone (lapis lazuli?) but has a distinctly lighter blue core around the perforation, therefore might have been produced artificially, blue glass? D: One elongated spherical bead made of glass, now pearlescent in colour. E: Two disc-shaped beads, one slightly larger … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Fragment of a seal-impression, the fine brown Nile clay has some mica inclusions and was hardened after excavation. The rear shows a concave impression of wood, possibly from a bold or know of a box or similar with three turned string impressions perpendicular to the wood. The side shows finger impressions. The top bears parts traces of one or more seal-impressions. At the top an seal-impression with a circumferential line. In the upper part a decorative curved element with partitioned into several segments by parallel vertical lines. Underneath a small standing baboon with hands raised in a gesture of adoration, to the right of it a disturbed area. Underneath this impression what looks like a second impression of either the same or a different seal, showing the top part preserved with a very small mn-sign (Y7) and a small sun-disc to the right of it.

description.value: A: Small rear- or hair-ring made of shell or bone, half broken off, one end preserved, getting thinner towards the end. B: Small pendant, made of carnelian, in the shape of a poppy seed, broken at the upper part along the perforation.  C: Half a spherical glass bead, corroded to a pearlescent and white colour, originally had a pattern of swirl lines around the perforation.  D: One elongated barrel-shaped bead made of white faience. E: Four dis-shaped beads made of faience, three of them white, one of the turquoise in colour.

description.value: Ear-ring made of jasper and 17 beads and several fragments in different shapes. A: Penannular ear-ring made of jasper, half of it preserved, one finished end preserved. The outer edge shows notches, no incised lines. The outer surface is well polished, the inner surface shows marks from the drill. B: Fragment of a spacer-bead made of turquoise faience, one segment partially preserved, quite cylindrical. C: Two barrel-shaped beads, one made of white faience, the smaller one made of reddish faience. D: Two flattened spherical beads, one much larger than the other, both made of white faience. E: Two ring-shaped beads, made of white faience. F: Two segmented cylindrical beads and several fragments, each complete with three segments, made of white faience. G: 8 disc-shaped beads and several fragments, 7 made of white faience, one in turquoise faience.

description.value: Ear-ring and 13 beads made in different material and shape. A: Fragment of an ear-ring in jasper, about half of it is preserved, one original end is still visible. The section is triangular and the surface is well polished, the inside shows drill lines. Along the edge an incised line on both sides and shallow notches along the edge. B: Flattened spherical bead made of a greyish-blackish glass, parts of the surface are chipped off, probably from a wrong firing temperature, the paste was not glazed properly.  C: Biconical bead made of a white stone with a sharp edge. D: One and a half cylindrical bead made of turquoise faience. E: Six disc-shaped beads, five of them made of ostrich eggshell, well rounded and smoothed, one made of turquoise faience. F: Two small barrel-shaped beads made of glass (?) paste, in a turquoise colour at the ends, white in the middle. G: One small stone (?) roughly ovoid, partly broken, well polished at the other parts, white with a brown line, no perforation.

description.value: Pair of hemispherical gold ball earrings with S-shaped hooks: earrings of the standard gold ball-and-disc type. The ball elements, forming less than a hemisphere, are made of two sections with a very neat vertical join. At the back they are finished with a flange 4 mm wide. A vertical supporting wire is attached at the back of the ball, and the end of the recurved hook is coiled around the end of it; the hook then runs up the back of the domed disc, about 9 mm in diameter, which is attached to the top of the ball. The join is concealed by a row of four gold grains.

description.value: Pair of hemispherical gold ball earrings with S-shaped hooks: earrings of the standard gold ball-and-disc type. The ball elements, forming less than a hemisphere, are made of two sections with a very neat vertical join. At the back they are finished with a flange 4 mm wide. A vertical supporting wire is attached at the back of the ball, and the end of the recurved hook is coiled around the end of it; the hook then runs up the back of the domed disc, about 9 mm in diameter, which is attached to the top of the ball. The join is concealed by a row of four gold grains.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Loop earring with pearls: an S-shaped gold loop earring made from a single wire finely tapered at both ends, one forming the point of the suspension hook, the other wound around the body of the wire to create the beaded ring. The decoration on the front of the loop consists of nine white pearls, all of somewhat irregular shape and graduated in size, the largest with a diameter of roughly 4 mm at the top. A tiny gold bead acts as a stop beneath the last pearl.

description.value: 1 ear-ring and 81 beads made in different shapes and materials: A: One fragment of an ear-ring made of white faience, roughly triangular in section but very flat.  B: Fragment of a spacer-bead made of white faience, two segments preserved, a third visible, flat. C: A raw bead, cylindrical in shape, roughly carved but not smoothed, the perforation broke through the outer surface. Another hint for bead production on site. D: Three elongated cylindrical beads, made of white faience. E: Three flattened spherical beads, made of white faience. F: One and a half ring-shaped beads, made of corroded glass, pearlescent in colour. G: 11 middle-sized disc-shaped beads, one made of ostrich eggshell, one made of turquoise faience, the rest made of white faience. H: 39 small disc-shaped beads, one made of red faience, four made of white faience, the rest made of beige faience.

description.value: Pair of gold ear-rings: concave disc surrounded by a ring of small leaves, and filled with a double rosette of eight leaves, with a pearl in the centre and six berries around it; above is an acanthus leaf and a honeysuckle ornament, with four small flowers below on each side; below are three pendants: central green plasma pendant in the form of an amphora with dolphin handles; on each side are three and four plaited chains respectively with pearl and plasma decoration; a hook is soldered to the back of each disc.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Pair of gold ear-rings: one of the earrings has lost all of its side pendants and some of the decorative berries within the central disc. The other earring has also lost some of these, but preserves the side pendants, with only the loss of the beads. Although missing some of their pendants, these earrings are intricately made, with careful attention to detail. They follow the common disc and amphora type of the middle and late Hellenistic period. These earrings have a highly decorated disc, above which is a large stylized floral motif, either a palmette or an acanthus leaf. This is soldered on to the main disc, which has a central motif in the form of a double rosette, with berries formed of tiny granules, some now missing, between each leaf. Small flowers further decorate the design, originally filled with blue-green plasma, the colour perhaps emulating the emerald, some of which survives. Below the disc hangs a large amphora, with dolphins forming its handles and an emerald for the body. The casing for the stone is decorated in a design familiar from vase painting and metal vessels. The foot of the amphora is in the form of a square box formed of sheet gold. Originally, on either side of the amphora hung pendants, and on one of the earrings the plaited chains and two of the pearl beads survive. A hook is soldered to the back of each disc.

description.value:
Pair of gold ear-rings.
Although missing some of their pendants, these earrings are intricately made, with careful attention to detail. They follow the common disc and amphora type of the middle and late Hellenistic period, but the use of a large emerald is unusual: emeralds became more popular during the Roman period.
These earrings have a highly decorated disc, above which is a large stylized floral motif, either a palmette or an acanthus leaf. This is soldered on to the main disc, which has a central motif in the form of a double rosette, with berries formed of tiny granules, some now missing, between each leaf. Small flowers further decorate the design, originally filled with blue-green enamel, the colour perhaps emulating the emerald, some of which survives. Below the disc hangs a large amphora, with dolphins forming its handles and an emerald for the body. The casing for the stone is decorated in a design familiar from vase painting and metal vessels. description.value: COMPASS Title: Pair of disc and amphora earrings linked by a long chain

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Pair of gold disc and amphora earrings linked by a long chain: the earrings are in good condition, missing only a few of the beads hanging from the elements attached to the main disc. There is also an emerald missing from one of the large discs. These elaborate earrings still preserve the chain, perhaps worn over the front of the body. The upper part of the earrings consists of a large disc with a garnet setting, capped by a finial in the form of a disc and feathered crown: a smaller garnet represents the discs, one of them conical, the other rounded, and the feathers were originally inlaid with a precious stone, now missing. The larger disc has an elaborate setting for the garnet, which is surrounded by a ring of granules, and the outer edge appears like a cogged wheel, each triangle embellished with tiny gold granules. At the sides of this disc are soldered hooks, from which hang pendants with small garnets and then a gold cone, from which three small chains with pearl, emerald and garnet beads (some missing) are suspended. From the bottom centre of the large disc a complicated fixing is soldered on, and from this hangs an amphora-shaped element. A large, almost spherical garnet represents the body of the vase, while the gold handles are in the form of dolphins. Delicate granulation work decorates the setting for the garnet. The foot of the vase is in the form of a square box to which the chain is attached.

description.value: Pair of gold ear-rings in the form of lynx heads and amphoras: the lynx head was made in two halves. Thin sheet gold would have been pressed over two bronze formers, the front and back pieces, and then the finer details added by chasing. Behind the collar there is a small garnet bead, while the hoop consists of a thin wire with additional wires twisted around it. The amphora pendant is elaborately decorated with granulation, a garnet for the body and a green glass bead at the bottom. Another pendant would originally have hung from the suspension hoop at the bottom, but is now missing on both earrings. A plaited wire chain hangs from the ring.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Pair of gold ear-rings: spirally twisted wire ring terminating in a lynx head, the neck decorated with a garnet bead and circles of globules; the narrow end is inserted into a gold loop below the mouth; below hangs an amphora pendant composed of an oval garnet bead with gold gold caps, decorated with granulation; below is a green glass bead; a plaited wire chain hangs from the ring.  Pair of gold ear-rings: wire ring with a loop at one end; below is soldered a disc decorated with filigree, with a round garnet in the centre and an ivy-leaf ornament on top; from the ring hangs an amphora pendant formed of a garnet set in gold; below the amphora hangs another disc with a round garnet in the centre and an ivy-leaf ornament below; a chain of 8-shaped link

description.value: Pendant earring: the earring is in a pale gold and is fairly crudely worked. The upper part of the ornament is a crescentic plaque with a symmetrical series of volutes below, formed of repoussé-gold sheet. An S-shaped hook is soldered to the back and the wire runs up to support a bead within the horns of the crescent. Hanging from three loops, which are attached behind the volutes, are wires covered by narrow cones of sheet gold, and terminating in beads. One of the suspended beads is hollow glass. The other beads appear to be pearls.

description.value: Loop earring with pearls: an S-shaped gold loop earring made from a single wire finely tapered at both ends, one forming the point of the suspension hook, the other wound around the body of the wire to create the beaded ring. The decoration on the front of the loop consists of nine white pearls, all of somewhat irregular shape and graduated in size, the largest with a diameter of roughly 4 mm at the top. A tiny gold bead acts as a stop beneath the last pearl.

description.value: One of a pair of gold earrings, set with a black glass seal engraved on one side with a head of Hermes wearing a winged cap, with a caduceus behind him; on the other side is a scorpion; the ring is S-shaped with chased parallel grooves along the hoop ending in a single large globule; the gem is held in place with a small concave plate on the bottom and a binding of gold wire which is twisted several times around the ring at the top; the gem is cracked across the front.

description.value: Mix of objects: two fragments of jasper ear-rings, one with a core from the drill, a jasper pendant, jasper raw stone fragments, 43 jasper beads, and eight copper alloy fragments probably from a wire A: fragment of a jasper ear-ring, a half circle is preserved, triangular in section, two circumferential lines running parallel to the edge, with small notches creating a ribbed edge, well polished at the outer surface. Traces of the drill in the inner face. This inner core has been completely drilled out but was still found with the ear-ring, proving a production on site.  B: small fragment of a jasper ear-ring, like A but in a smaller size, remains of copper alloy corroded onto the object in one corner. C: small jasper pendant in the shape of a kind of flower. The rear is flat and the upper side is textured to shape of the petals. The perforation is partly broken off. Copper alloy remains corroded onto the surface at the rear. The surface is still unfinished and not very smooth.  D: smal… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Pair of gold ear-rings.
These elaborate earrings consist of a central amphora-shaped pendant, above and below which discs are attached. All three elements are formed from sheet gold and contain cabochon garnets. The upper disc is the most elaborate, with the garnet set into a disc formed from concentric circles. The outer circle has tiny gold granules soldered to it, the inner one is formed from a twisted wire. An inverted heart-shaped motif is cut from the same gold sheet as the disc, behind which the hoop is attached.
The amphora pendant hangs from the upper disc by means of a loop, which is attached to a hollow tube incised to appear like twisted wire. This element also forms the neck of the vessel. The looped handles of the amphora are formed from gold wire, looped at the top and bottom. The amphora is soldered on to a box fitting incorporating the foot of the vessel, but also acting as the suspension loop for the disc element below. This disc, plainer than the upper one, i… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Gold ear stud, one of pair. The disc is pan-shaped with an upturned edge rimmed with beaded wire. Within the disc are concentric bands of spiral-beaded, plain and rope filigree, and friezes of simple filigree running spirals and complex spirals with omega fillers, all in spiral-beaded wire. In the centre of the disc is a three-tiered flower-head, its convex petals bordered in spiral-beaded wire, surmounted by a large central granule.
One disc of the pair retains its back stud, which has a die-formed star-burst within a spiral-beaded and plain wire border. There are no signs of any safety chain or cord.

description.value: Ewer, silver-gilt. Richly embossed and chased. Classical form comprising oviform body, short stem and small foot, with high spout and handle. Decorated in Mannerist style with scenes of Neptune and Amphitrite, executed in low relief, each within a roundel in the middle of either side of the ewer. Remainder of body covered in elaborate strapwork filled with terms, masks, grotesques, snails, snakes and foliage. Lower spout supported by upraised hands of a caryatid female figure applied to front of ewer, her feet resting on the head of a horned mask with beard and pointed ears. Spout ends in form of a beast's neck terminating in a horned goat-like head. Terminal of handle in form of a Pan-like satyr with hooves resting on a bracket of scrolling strapwork above the head of a female mask framed by looped drapery. The projecting lip is richly embossed withn a half-animal, half-human mask. Handle rises in sharp curve to form limb of a reptile gripping the scalp of a male mask surrounded by drapery. Marked.

description.value: Silver-gilt ewer richly embossed and chased that the upper part of the neck and a small section of the handle are virtually the only surfaces that have been left plain. The essentially classical form comprises an oviform body on a short, narrow stem and a relatively small foot, with a high spout and handle, the latter rising up in a steep u-curve above the neck-rim. However, the decorative detail is entirely drawn from the repertoire of Mannerist art and transforms the ewer into a sculptural masterpiece of Antwerp Mannerism.  The two principal subjects are Neptune and Amphitrite, executed in low relief, each contained within a roundel (DIAM. 6.2 cm) in the middle of either side of the ewer. Both are represented riding a sea-monster across the waves with windblown drapery behind them and blowing a large conch shell (or marine trumpet) held in one hand. The bearded and dishevelled Neptune holds in his raised left hand his trident, which points vertically downwards and rests on the ferocious, ugly head of the monster he sits astride. Neptune's cloak, fastened by a brooch at the neck, billows out behind him to the right, leaving his torso naked, though his thighs and legs are covered in drapery that merges into the waves. The sinuous body and tail of the monster curve away to the left. By contrast, Amphitrite is depicted fully clad in classical-style drapery; she is shown sitting sideways on an equally fearsome monster through whose open jaws are passed the lightest of thin reins that loop up over her right shoulder. Amphitrite's right hand is raised as if to smooth her immaculate coiffure. The remainder of the body of the ewer is covered in elaborate strapwork, filled with terms, masks, grotesques, snails, snakes and restless foliage. The simple strapwork frames of the two roundels are linked by a broad horizontal strapwork band, dividing the body of the ewer into a broad upper zone and the much larger lower zone. In the upper zone, above the Amphitrite roundel, there are, facing each other, a pair of long-necked, female-headed, sphinxes or animal grotesques with long, dragon-like tails and scaly bodies with spiky spines; in between them, a horned goat (?) mask is in high relief on a strapwork cartouche, behind which squats a winged figure, whose head, legs and arms emerge and whose hands grasp the spiralling sprays of foliage. In the upper zone, above the Neptune roundel, there are, facing each other, a pair of fantastic animal grotesques with scaly bodies, spiky spines and horned, fearsome heads; in between them is a lion's mask on a strapwork cartouche, behind which squats a ghoulish winged satyr with horns, whose head, legs and hooves emerge and whose hands grasp the spiralling foliage stalks. At the front, in this upper zone, the spout emerges in the form of a beast's long scaly neck terminating in a horned goat-like monster-head. The lower part of the spout is supported by the upraised hands of the caryatid female figure, executed almost fully in the round and applied to the front of the ewer; she is clad in a classical-style, almost Greek, drapery and wears a diadem on her head; the sandals on her feet rest on the head of a fantastic horned mask with a beard and pointed ears. At the back, in the upper zone, the terminal of the handle occupies the corresponding position and takes the form of a Pan-like satyr, executed almost fully in the round and applied to the body of the ewer. The satyr stands, arms akimbo, the upper part of the arms trapped under two broad coils of the divided ends of the handle; the satyr's hooves rest on a bracket of scrolling strapwork above the head of a female mask wearing a foliate diadem and framed by

description.value: Ewer; silver-gilt; embossed and chased; spout in form of goat's head supported by draped female figure standing on mask of Pan; handle a flat band rising from a figure of Pan who stands on a female mask, and terminating in a goat-like monster; oviform body with two circular medallions, Neptune and Amphitrite fully draped; body ornamented with strapwork, terminal figures and two pairs of monsters; ground covered with floral scrolls in relief; birds and scrolls in relief on foot; inscribed.

description.value: After cleaning in 2009. Work done by Julie Percheron, conservation intern in CGM, December 2009.Ewer, silver-gilt. Richly embossed and chased. Classical form comprising oviform body, short stem and small foot, with high spout and handle. Decorated in Mannerist style with scenes of Neptune and Amphitrite, executed in low relief, each within a roundel in the middle of either side of the ewer. Remainder of body covered in elaborate strapwork filled with terms, masks, grotesques, snails, snakes and foliage. Lower spout supported by upraised hands of a caryatid female figure applied to front of ewer, her feet resting on the head of a horned mask with beard and pointed ears. Spout ends in form of a beast's neck terminating in a horned goat-like head. Terminal of handle in form of a Pan-like satyr with hooves resting on a bracket of scrolling strapwork above the head of a female mask framed by looped drapery. The projecting lip is richly embossed withn a half-animal, half-human mask. Handle rises in sharp curve to form limb of a reptile gripping the scalp of a male mask surrounded by drapery. Marked.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum
